messageBody:
Kevin,

Yep, that can be a pain. I've only gotten bit by it once every couple
weeks, which is about half as often as I appreciate the fact that
quick-fix on

assertThat(myNewMethod(), is("abc"));

creates

String myNewMethod() {
}

so for me, hamcrest does optimize for the common case.

That said, you could pretty easily write your own matcher, if this
came up a lot. I tried once to figure out how to automatically get
the stricter typing when I wanted it, and the looser when I didn't,
but there's always trade-offs to be made. If you do end up writing
your own, (1) consider submitting it to hamcrest, and (2) let me know
what the name is (I can't think of a good one).

On the meta-question, the developers hang around
hamcrest-dev@... (which I've CC'ed), so they can pipe in
with further ideas. There's also hamcrest-java@..., but
I don't know if anyone listens there. Hamcrest will soon be shipping
along with JUnit, so I figure ours won't be the last hamcrest
question. Thanks,

David Saff

On 7/5/07, Kevin Lawrence <kev.lawrence@...> wrote:
> I have been playing with Hamcrest a little and I keep running across a
> problem with generic type being mismatched in assertThat().
>
> Example:
>
> Object actual = "a string";
> assertThat(actual, is("a string"));
>
> The compiler says:
>
> <T>assertThat(T, Matcher<T>) cannot be applied to (Object, Matcher<String>)
>
> I can work around it by casting the expected value to object, or the actual
> value to String...
>
> assertThat(actual, is((object) "a string"));
>
> Am I doing something wrong? Is there a better approach? A better workaround?
> Should I just suck it up?
>
> Another list where I should be asking questions about Hamcrest?
>
> --
> Kevin
>
> http://www.junitfactory.com
> You send us code. We send you tests. For free.
